title: What is the Happiest Country on Earth -- And Why?

comments.text:
Forty years after the Swedish parliament unanimously decided to change the 
formerly homogenous Sweden into a multicultural country, violent crime has 
increased by 300% and rapes by 1,472%. Sweden is now number two on the list 
of rape countries, surpassed only by Lesotho in Southern Africa.
Significantly, the report does not touch on the background of the rapists. 
One should, however, keep in mind that in statistics, second-generation 
immigrants are counted as Swedes.
In an astounding number of cases, the Swedish courts have demonstrated 
sympathy for the rapists, and have acquitted suspects who have claimed that 
the girl wanted to have sex with six, seven or eight men.
The internet radio station Granskning Sverige called the mainstream 
newspapers Aftonposten and Expressen to ask why they had described the 
perpetrators as "Swedish men" when they actually were Somalis without 
Swedish citizenship. They were hugely offended when asked if they felt any 
responsibility to warn Swedish women to stay away from certain men. One 
journalist asked why that should be their responsibility.﻿

comments.text:
What is happy? I think when you live in West- Europe.. you are always 
happy! If you live in Spain, Portugal, Belgium, France or Germany.. it 
doesn't matter.. your life will be perfect!

But, okay.. if we are talking about the happiest country on earth! I really 
think that the Netherlands and Denmark are the happiest countries!
Okay okay, I am from Holland! But I will never leave this country! This 
country is perfect!!
Friendly people, everyone have a job, a lot of cycling, very small (in 4 
hours you are from the north to the south. And in 45 minutes you are from 
Amsterdam to Rotterdam).. everyone is healthy, you can eat very well in 
this country and studying in the Netherlands is also very good.  I can't 
describe it.. it is amazing in the Netherlands! I can't find a reason to 
leave this country.﻿
comments.author: FRL LFC

comments.text:
"Socialism: is a dirty word to Americans but it simply means that the 
government owns and controls all the means of production and distribution. 
The so-called "Socialist" countries are really capitalist countries who 
make sure that people have good health care and good pensions. The right 
wing (ie the Republicans) want you to believe that the  so-called 
"socialist" countries are bad. If you believe them you are a bit stupid. 
Those so-called "socialist" countries are where people are healthier, 
happier and live longer. You are correct, Young Turks. Don't be fooled, 
Americans.﻿
comments.author: Donald Edward

comments.text:
Actually, Republicans are, in my opinion, right when they say that the 
market needs to be less regulated. The only thing is that the Swedish 
industries aren't that heavily regulated. Depending on which U.S. state one 
is comparing with, Sweden actually has lower corporate taxes than what 
American companies have to cope with. I think welfare and happiness in 
Sweden are crucially related to the corporate-friendly environment. Our 
welfare programs are depending on business going well, and that's why we 
have a system which is both corporate-friendly AND citizen-friendly. A 
concept that neither the Democrats nor the Republicans seem willing to try 
out.
//A Republican-leaning libertarian Swede who used to live in Virginia﻿

comments.author: Ben Weber

comments.text:
ON NATIONAL SOCIALISM AND WORLD RELATIONS
 

SPEECH DELIVERED IN THE GERMAN REICHSTAG ON JANUARY 30TH 1937
by Adolf Hitler
FÜHRER AND CHANCELLOR
 

This session of the Reichstag takes place on a date which is full of 
significance for the German people. Four years have passed since the 
beginning of that great internal revolution which in the meantime has been 
giving a new aspect to German life. This is the period of four years which 
I asked the German people to grant me for the purpose of putting my work to 
the test and submitting it to their judgment. Hence at the present moment 
nothing could be more opportune than for me to render you an account of all 
the successes that have been achieved and the progress that has been made 
during these four years, for the welfare of the German people. But within 
the limits of the short statement I have to make it would be entirely 
impossible to enumerate all the remarkable results that have been reached 
during a time which may be looked upon as probably the most astounding 
epoch in the life of our people. That task belongs rather to the press and 
the propaganda. Moreover, during the course of the present year there will 
be an Exposition here in Berlin which is being organized for the purpose of 
giving a more comprehensive and detailed picture of the works that have 
been completed, the results that have been obtained and the projects on 
which work has been begun, all of which can be explained better in this way 
than I could do it within the limits of an address that is to last for two 
hours. Therefore I shall utilize the opportunity afforded me by this 
historic meeting of the Reichstag to cast a glance back over the past four 
years and call attention to some of the new knowledge that we have gained, 
some of the experiences which we have been through, and the consequences 
that have resulted therefrom—in so far as there have a general validity. It 
is important that we should understand them clearly, not only for our own 
sake but also for that of the generations to come.
comments.author: Ben Weber

comments.text:
+Ben Weber wrote > Hitler had the ebst economy in the world udner 
socialism, 

----

Denmark is right next to Germany ... so I know all about Hitler and the 
Nazi rule during WW2 ... Hitler was a far-right anti-communist, 
anti-Jewish, atheist fascist and it's both insulting and laughable to even 
try to pin him and his fascist Nazi ideology on Scandinavian socialism and 
social democracy, which is all about respecting all minorities and the 
equal right to freedom of expression for all people and the equal access to 
a higher education, so that all people get the chance to better themselves, 
to the benefit of all.

Hitler and his fascist Nazi ideology had no respect for minorities or 
political opponents, or for the right to freedom of expression for all 
people. He was burning books, exterminating and deporting political 
opponents ...

Unlike most of the rest of Europe, the Danes saved almost all of it's 
Jewish population from Hitler and the Nazis, so that over 99% of Denmark's 
Jews survived the Holocaust.
.

comments.text:
Finland has 16 suicides per 100 000 citizens, US has 12,5 per 100 000 
citizes, sweden has 12,  and norway has 11,9. Canada 11,5 and denmark 11,3.
What explanatory factors there are is hard to say, but i would say that use 
of alcohol ad isolation could be contributing factors.
The biggest common denominators seem to be cold weather and darkness 
though. And as a Swedish citizen with an medicated anxiety disorder i can 
agree that 6 months of darkness is quite tough, especially while drunk and 
single. (haha) I don't think you can draw any lines between suicide rates 
and "happiness" though. suicide may not allways imply lack of happiness, it 
may well be lack of good coping methods for periods of hardship.
Suicide is, accourding to statistics very uncommon in, for exampel, Syria. 
I dont think that means that the Syrian model of governance is preferable 
to raise levels of happiness.
comments.author: Hrnk 444

comments.text:
+Tobina Ryuu
 You know that's the average per 100k inhabitans right? You can't just add 
them you have to calculate with the increased population of all the 
countries.

I'll show you some calculations that should end up with a number somewhere 
between the highest number and the lowest (be warned messy math ahead):

First Scandinavia (I'll do the Nordic countries later) is:
Denmark: Population about 5.65 million and 11.3 suicides per 100k per 
year     5,650,000/100,000=56.5     56.5*11.3=638 Suicides per year.
Norway: Population about 5.13 million and 11.9 suicides per 100k per 
year     5,130,000/100,000=51.3     51.3*11.9=610 Suicides per year.
Sweden Population about 9.71 million and 12.0 suicides per 100k per year   
  9,710,000/100,000=97.1     97.1*12=1165 Suicides per year.

Now to add them together: 5.65+5.13+9.71=20.49 million inhabitants    
638+610+1165=2,413 Suicides per year
2,413/20,490,000=0.0001176        0.0001176*100,000=11.77 Suicides per 100k 
per year
So it is 11.77 not 39.9

And as promised Nordic countries:
Finland: Population about 5.47 million and 16.0 suicides per 100k per 
year     5,470,000/100,000=54.7     54.7*16=875 Suicides per year.
Iceland: Population about 325 thousand and 11.3 suicides per 100k per 
year     325,000/100,000=3.25     3.25*11.3=37 Suicides per year.
And the Scandinavian countries: population 20.49 million     2413 Suicides 
per year

Adding again: 20,490,000+5,470,000+325,000=26.285 million inhabitants     
2413+875+37=3,325 Suicides per year
3,325/26,285,000=0.0001265       0.0001265*100,000=12,65 Suicides per 100k 
per year
A total of 12.65 Suicides per 100k per year with all five Nordic countries.

comments.text:
That is a general misunderstanding. They do not know the concept of the 
Danish "Feriepenge". I think, Sweden has a similar system.
Feriepenge is like an obligatory saving for holidays. 12,5% of your salary 
is held back to be paid out when you are on holiday and do not earn any 
money on the job.
The alternative is holiday with salary. Your salary is calculates so that 
it includes the right to 5 weeks of non-working while still getting your 
normal salary.

comments.text:
+Whalturk +Zorin Stahlheim  Actually, atheism deals with theism while 
agnosticism deals with gnosticism. One is about belief, about some 
supernatural claim and belief in its correctness, other is about knowledge, 
whether something is actually knowable.
You can be gnostic atheist, agnostic atheist, agnostic theist or gnostic 
theist. In crude these translate to knowing there is no god, not being sure 
there is no god, not being sure there is a god and being sure that there is 
a god. Most atheist are in actuality agnostic atheist.
This definition of agnostic that many have is just a placeholder for "I 
don't want to pick sides", while the real definition of an agnostic atheist 
is that s/he does not believe in (specific) religion, but does not think 
deity can be known to either exist or not exist.
Evolution does not require belief, it is a (scientific) theory same as 
gravity, just better understood and studied.
comments.author: Deivid

atheists and agnostics accept scientific facts (which evolution is).

comments.author: Darth Kaujas

comments.text:
+Kim Vennevold I think you might exaggerate this a little. What I know it's 
usually not 50C in the summer, pretty hot sometimes but not that hot. And 
it's usually not as cold as -15 degrees either, it could be at least in the 
north, but usually a bit warmer. The hours of sun varies a lot from summer 
to winter. In Stockholm during the summer the sun rise about 3.30-4.30AM 
and then the sun set is at about 21-22PM during the winter the sun rise 
about 7-8.30AM and sets at about a bit before 3-5PM. But it's also a pretty 
big difference between the north and the south parts of Sweden, in the very 
north the sun never rise during a part of the winter and never sets during 
a part of the summer. To explain this better for those who don't live in 
Sweden, to me the winter is kinda depressing and dark and cold, in December 
it's usually dark outside when you go to school and dark again when it's 
time to go home. On the other hand, the summer in Sweden is really nice, 
warm but not way too warm and never too dark.
comments.author: Rebecka Strohl

comments.text: Right now in my area of England its still reaching 20 degrees c :L
comments.author: Il Valentino

comments.text:
+Mirko GF It varies a lot. But in general, there is a lot of snow, and the 
temperatures can very low,but usually not more than -20.
We had four "hard winters" in a row (four months of ice cold winter), then 
there was one which was slightly milder, and then it was very cold again 
last year. 

I´d say that the temperatures are, generally, not as cold as in Canada -but 
they sure as hell can be ;)
comments.author: Mickey Holm

comments.text:
Is the Scandinavian winter longer than Canadian one? here in November 
normally we have snow and temperatures below -3c, -10c... January and 
February tons of snow with average temperature - 20 without wind and few 
weeks -45C. March still cold but not that much -15C... on April we have the 
last snowstorm and temperatures -2, -5 etc... (Montreal) Is it the same 
there?
comments.author: M GF

comments.text:
+Kim Vennevold In the netherlands when we have the longest day (the point 
where the sun reaches the highest). Around that time it gets dark at about 
11pm, 23:00. So in Sweden it even gets lighter. (remembering a summer 
vacation somewhere in sweden. Fishing at sundown around 0:30 at night) As 
for an other time in Oslo (norway) i remember waking up at about midnight, 
thinking it was morning cause the sun was still up. The whole US is on the 
map in europe: everything south of the north border of Italy. So yes, it is 
alot darker in the countries north of there. But in the summer the sun sets 
much later. If it even sets at all in northern scandinavia.
comments.author: Rens de Graaf

comments.text: +Espen Thomassen That did help. Thanks. 👍
comments.author: Jeremy Sears

comments.text:
The weather varies a lot in norther Europe/Scandinavia. Overall, it IS 
colder and darker in the north, but it can get very hot too, but never to 
the extreme, and that is a good thing in my opinion, that way you don´t 
grow tired of the weather been the same all year ;)
comments.author: Mickey Holm

comments.text:
+Kim Vennevold And if I may add, those temperatures are in celsius, not 
fahrenheit for all you americans.
comments.author: Espen Thomassen

comments.text:
That's not true. We have cool spring, hot summer, chilly autumn and cold 
winter. The average temperature is 5-10 in spring, 20-30 in summer, 10-15 
in autumn and -15 in winter. And of course warmer down south and colder up 
north. In the sun the temperature can reach high as 50 and low as -40 in 
some areas. And it's usually light from 5 AM to 6 PM mostly but during 
summer it doesn't get dark until after 8-9 PM. Only the winter is dark most 
of the days but not much longer than otherwise and up north it's dark only 
a for a few hours.
comments.author: Roffel Swagman
